channel.title: Ram
channel.description:
I'm thinking of adding more RAM to my computer as it is getting awfully slow, but I've never done it before. I don't want to buy the wrong type just to find out it isn't compatible with my computer, so if anyone could help me I'd appreciated it.
Operating System: Windows 7 Home Premium 32-bit (6.1, Build 7601) System Manufacturer: Gateway System Model: GT5220 BIOS: Phoenix - Award WorkstationBIOS v6.00PG Processor: AMD Athlon(tm) 64 X2 Dual Core Processor 3800+ (2 CPUs), ~2.0GHz Memory: 1024MB RAM Available OS Memory: 896MB RAM
Edit: This is what I've found so far: http://www.crucial.com/store/mpartspecs.aspx?mtbpoid=2DC0A8F1A5CA7304 http://www.crucial.com/systemscanner/viewscanbyid.aspx?id=C2B1A85631D926C3

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:17, topic:417839”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=520388.msg3780830#msg3780830 date=1318460653]
Anything over 4 is useless on a 32-bit system.
[/quote]

That isn’t quite true: some 32-bit processors support something called physical address extension (PAE) which allows you to address 64 gigabytes of physical memory, however, each individual program can still only use up to 4 gigabytes of virtual memory.

Nevertheless, PAE is a bit of a hack and getting a 64-bit system is much better in many aspects (not just from the increased amount of address space - instructions are encoded more efficiently, there are more registers, compilers can assume you have features like SSE and thus output faster code by default, etc.)[/quote]
Thanks for that, taught me something important:D.

In general guys don’t under estimate 32bit Computers… Mines is a 2010 Gaming computer, at the time I got this computer there were still quite a few issues with 64bit so I decided to stick with 32bit. 32Bit is good, just not good for business use, more personal use… Next computer i’m going 64bit however although that won’t be for a while considering my comp still rapes ;d.

Read full topic

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

zyle1992:

Anything over 4 is useless on a 32-bit system.

That isn’t quite true: some 32-bit processors support something called physical address extension (PAE) which allows you to address 64 gigabytes of physical memory, however, each individual program can still only use up to 4 gigabytes of virtual memory.

Nevertheless, PAE is a bit of a hack and getting a 64-bit system is much better in many aspects (not just from the increased amount of address space - instructions are encoded more efficiently, there are more registers, compilers can assume you have features like SSE and thus output faster code by default, etc.)

Read full topic

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @synchronized2 synchronized_
item.description:
@synchronized2 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:15, topic:417839”][quote author=synchronized_ link=topic=520388.msg3780822#msg3780822 date=1318460134]

Just adding more RAM isn’t going to make it much faster.

Well what does make it faster? I’ve been looking at RAM this whole time, and your saying if I changed my 4GB to a 16GB it won’t do a lot?

It’ll make it faster, yes but it wouldn’t make THAT much of a difference. If you really want a quicker and more snappier PC you’ll probably need to upgrade both the RAM and the CPU (Unless you already have a beast CPU :D)

You have to pay attention to the RAM timings (them numbers that look like 7-7-7-21). This is how fast the RAM can process data, basically. (They refer to how many CPU cycles (ticks) it takes for the RAM to ready the data). Also, you’ll need to look at the maximum speed of the RAM (e.g: 1600mhz); you’re not going to get this speed just by putting them into your computer (They’d most probably run at 1333mhz). That speed is the maximum it’s able to run at which means you’ll need to overclock your RAM to get it to run that fast and the more RAM the harder it is to overclock. Also, the more you overclock the more unstable the system is; to make it more stable you’ll have to increase the RAM timings (therefore making it slower).

So, the point is, getting fuck loads of RAM isn’t always the best thing. I’d say anywhere from 4-6GB is enough. Sorry I’m not very good at explaining things.
[/quote]

Anything over 4 is useless on a 32-bit system.[/quote]
ololol. Oops. I didn’t even read his first post properly. My bad.

Read full topic

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“synchronized_, post:14, topic:417839”][quote author=Fridder link=topic=520388.msg3780589#msg3780589 date=1318448984]

Just adding more RAM isn’t going to make it much faster.

Well what does make it faster? I’ve been looking at RAM this whole time, and your saying if I changed my 4GB to a 16GB it won’t do a lot?
[/quote]
It’ll make it faster, yes but it wouldn’t make THAT much of a difference. If you really want a quicker and more snappier PC you’ll probably need to upgrade both the RAM and the CPU (Unless you already have a beast CPU :D)

You have to pay attention to the RAM timings (them numbers that look like 7-7-7-21). This is how fast the RAM can process data, basically. (They refer to how many CPU cycles (ticks) it takes for the RAM to ready the data). Also, you’ll need to look at the maximum speed of the RAM (e.g: 1600mhz); you’re not going to get this speed just by putting them into your computer (They’d most probably run at 1333mhz). That speed is the maximum it’s able to run at which means you’ll need to overclock your RAM to get it to run that fast and the more RAM the harder it is to overclock. Also, the more you overclock the more unstable the system is; to make it more stable you’ll have to increase the RAM timings (therefore making it slower).

So, the point is, getting fuck loads of RAM isn’t always the best thing. I’d say anywhere from 4-6GB is enough. Sorry I’m not very good at explaining things.[/quote]

Anything over 4 is useless on a 32-bit system.

Read full topic

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @synchronized2 synchronized_
item.description:
@synchronized2 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:10, topic:417839”][quote author=synchronized_ link=topic=520388.msg3780442#msg3780442 date=1318435858]
Just adding more RAM isn’t going to make it much faster.
[/quote]

Well what does make it faster? I’ve been looking at RAM this whole time, and your saying if I changed my 4GB to a 16GB it won’t do a lot?[/quote]
It’ll make it faster, yes but it wouldn’t make THAT much of a difference. If you really want a quicker and more snappier PC you’ll probably need to upgrade both the RAM and the CPU (Unless you already have a beast CPU :D)

You have to pay attention to the RAM timings (them numbers that look like 7-7-7-21). This is how fast the RAM can process data, basically. (They refer to how many CPU cycles (ticks) it takes for the RAM to ready the data). Also, you’ll need to look at the maximum speed of the RAM (e.g: 1600mhz); you’re not going to get this speed just by putting them into your computer (They’d most probably run at 1333mhz). That speed is the maximum it’s able to run at which means you’ll need to overclock your RAM to get it to run that fast and the more RAM the harder it is to overclock. Also, the more you overclock the more unstable the system is; to make it more stable you’ll have to increase the RAM timings (therefore making it slower).

So, the point is, getting fuck loads of RAM isn’t always the best thing. I’d say anywhere from 4-6GB is enough. Sorry I’m not very good at explaining things.

Read full topic

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @Stupit Stu
item.description:
@Stupit wrote:

[quote=“Exion, post:7, topic:417839”][quote author=Hidendra link=topic=520388.msg3779400#msg3779400 date=1318342924]

Take a peek here at the specs for GT5220 - http://support.gateway.com/s/PC/R/1009151/1009151sp3.shtml

It says it supports up to 4 GB of ram, and it has to be DDR2 (not DDR3!) It also has a limit of 1 GB per stick/slot.

Thanks. This is what I was looking at: http://www.crucial.com/store/mpartspecs.aspx?mtbpoid=AD75055CA5CA7304

Yeah, that website is accurate for most computers so what it says is correct
[/quote]
Alright, one more thing.

One of them has

DDR2 PC2-5300 • CL=5 • Unbuffered • NON-ECC • DDR2-667 • 1.8V • 128Meg x 64

and the other has

DDR2 PC2-6400 • CL=6 • Unbuffered • NON-ECC • DDR2-800 • 1.8V • 128Meg x 64

I’m guessing the second one is better?[/quote]
You’d be correct.

Read full topic

I’m guessing the second one is better?

item.title: Ram
item.dc:creator: @hidendra Hidendra
item.description:
@hidendra wrote:

[quote=“Exion, post:3, topic:417839”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=520388.msg3779272#msg3779272 date=1318321125]
AMD Athlon® 64 X2 3800+, dual core processor with AMD64 technology

2.0 GHz
200 MHz system bus
512KB × L2 cache

That’s pretty bad.

Do you have 4 RAM slots or 2?

If 4: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820134596
If 2: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E168201466

That is of course assuming you don’t upgrade to 64-bit.
[/quote]
Yes, I know it’s bad. This computer is pretty old.

I have 4 slots, but how do I know if that is compatible?[/quote]
Take a peek here at the specs for GT5220 - http://support.gateway.com/s/PC/R/1009151/1009151sp3.shtml

It says it supports up to 4 GB of ram, and it has to be DDR2 (not DDR3!) It also has a limit of 1 GB per stick/slot.
